Influence of heteroatom-doped Fe-carbon sphere catalysts on CO2- mediated oxidative dehydrogenation of ethylbenzene Anindya Ghosh a Aniruddha Singha a Rupak Chatterjee b Thomas E. Müller c Asim Bhaumik b Biswajit Chowdhury a ⁎ a Department of Chemistry, Indian Institute of Technology (ISM), Dhanbad, Jharkhand, India Department of Chemistry Indian Institute of Technology (ISM) Dhanbad Jharkhand India aDepartment of Chemistry, Indian Institute of Technology (ISM), Dhanbad, Jharkhand, India b School of Materials Science, Indian Association for the Cultivation of Science, Kolkata, India School of Materials Science Indian Association for the Cultivation of Science Kolkata India bSchool of Materials Science, Indian Association for the Cultivation of Science, Kolkata, India c Carbon Sources and Conversion, Ruhr-Universität Bochum, Universitätsstraße 150, Bochum 44801, Germany Carbon Sources and Conversion Ruhr-Universität Bochum Universitätsstraße 150 Bochum 44801 Germany cCarbon Sources and Conversion, Ruhr-Universität Bochum, Universitätsstraße 150, Bochum 44801, Germany ⁎ Corresponding author. Distinctly shaping carbon materials together with doping is an excellent approach for tailoring advanced materials. In this study, a series of heteroatom (N, S, P)-doped Fe-carbon sphere catalysts were prepared by a hydrothermal process to explore the effect of unary and binary dopants on the CO2-mediated ethyl benzene oxidative dehydrogenation. Upon doing so, a transformation from quasi to hollow to perfect spheres was observed that takes place due to the increasing hydrolysis rate and attainment of supersaturation. It was shown that each type of heteroatom has a beneficial role in creating specific chemical entities as well as in defining the iron amount of the catalyst. Catalytic activity correlated with XPS and Raman analysis reveal that the direct dehydrogenation of ethylbenzene is controlled by the iron content at low temperatures, while defect sites are the controlling parameter at high temperatures. Under oxidative conditions, the N-doped hierarchical Fe-hollow sphere carbon (Fe-N-C) catalyst shows the highest catalytic performance among all synthesized catalysts due to the cooperative action of pyridinic N species and the Fe3C phase for CO2 activation as well as RWGS reaction promotion. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords CO2 Soft oxidant Oxidative dehydrogenation Carbon sphere Heteroatom-doped Data availability The data that has been used is confidential. 1 Introduction Carbon nanomaterials with distinct shapes and structures have gained global recognition from academia and industry due to their superior properties like high surface area, good thermal stability and electrical conductivity, and chemical inertness which enables widespread applications in various fields such as adsorbents, catalysts, catalyst supports, energy storage, electrode material, drug delivery and so forth [1–3]. Porous carbon spheres receive particular interest as they possess adequate structural stability, a high surface-to-volume ratio, and an empty space for accommodating metal ions [4]. The advantages of spherical carbon as heterogeneous catalyst support far outweigh that conventional non-spherical materials as it provides faster diffusion and transfer of reactants and products, and good pore accessibility [3]. The deactivation of a supported metal catalyst is frequently the biggest problem of a heterogeneous catalyst and often takes place owing to the sintering or agglomeration of metal nanoparticles [3]. The encapsulation of metal nanoparticles inside the core of the carbon structure is an effective strategy to solve this problem. Generally, the coupling of pentagonal and heptagonal rings cause the carbon nanospheres, where graphitic sheets are more likely to turn out to be a curved along a sphere, to have reactive bonds at the surface which is unlike in the case of C60 [1]. The size of typical carbon spheres ranges from 50 nm to10 μm and can be controlled by varying the reaction temperature and the concentration of precursor species. So far, several strategies have been adopted to prepare carbon nanosphere such as CVD, hydrothermal carbonization (HTC), soft and hard templating, modified Stöber process, and others [3]. Among these low-temperature HTC process is the oldest and easiest approach comprising decomposition of the sugar-based system into HMF followed by polymerization and polycondensation. The introduction of heteroatoms inside the carbon framework is a promising approach in order to change its surface chemistry. The heteroatoms (B, N, S, P) impose unpaired electron density inside the sp2-ring causing the strengthening of the host-guest interaction that eventually alters the catalytic activity [5]. Nitrogen and oxygen doped carbons are extensively studied and widely used materials owing to diverse range of properties. For example, oxygen doping is responsible for developing acidic, basic, or bifunctional acid-base characteristics of carbon depending on the carbonization temperature. In contrast, due to the electronegativity differences between nitrogen and carbon (Pauling scale χ O :3.344, χ N :3.04, χ C :2.44), doping with nitrogen polarizes the carbon framework in a more stable way and promotes the interactions of the carbon surface with acidic molecules through covalent bonding, hydrogen bonding, and dipole-dipole interactions. In a word, nitrogen doping enhances the basic properties of carbon. Likewise, S and P doping induces lots of structural defect sites due to the comparably large size of the S and P atoms apart from delivering acidic functionalities at the edge or outer surface of the carbon materials. Interestingly, the presence of sulfur atoms prevents the sintering of metal nanoparticles at high temperatures. In recent times, binary or tertiary heteroatoms doped carbon material have opened a new domain in the field of catalysis due to their unique electron distribution and cooperative effect [2,6]. Recently, our group experimentally and theoretically showed the synergistic effect between pyridine N and surface -SO2H of N, S co-doped carbon is essential in order to obtain effective CO2 fixation performances [2]. Wu et al. pointed out that the synergistic effect of P, N, and S triggers the electrocatalytic oxygen reduction reaction [7]. Further, Hu et al. mentioned that a porous structure is also beneficial along with N, S active sites while performing nitroarene reduction and ethylbenzene oxidation using N, S co-doped carbon catalysts [8]. Mostly, a stepwise introduction pathway is followed for the co-doped carbon materials which often requires harmful precursors (H2S, NH3) and sophisticated instruments (plasma treatment, chemical vapor deposition, ball milling) [9]. Thus, compositional co-doping with environmentally friendly chemicals in a simple way such as hydrothermal synthesis is highly desirable to develop a sustainable economy. Reducing the CO2 concentration is of increasing global concern and net-zero carbon emissions need to be achieved in the near future. In this respect, utilization of CO2 in the form of capture, storage, and conversion is a good approach to meet the target of long-term sustainable production and establish a carbon-neutral economy [10]. Among various technologies, utilizing CO2 as C1 raw material for the production of chemicals and fuels is a promising as well as indispensable strategy for generating anthropogenic carbon cycles [11]. To date, numerous chemical compounds have been synthesized from CO2 such as formic acid, urea, cyclic carbonates, salicylic acid, methanol olefins, dimethyl carbonates, etc. [12–15]. Nevertheless, those are not sufficient to meet the climate target within a short time. For providing an ecologically and economically beneficial entry to production chains of the chemical industry, new routes and technologies will have to be developed. In this perspective, utilizing CO2 as a soft oxidant and promoter in catalytic processes is an attractive addition in the area of CO2 mitigation. A highly attractive application of CO2 is the synthesis of styrene through oxidative dehydrogenation (ODH) of ethylbenzene (Scheme 1 ). As styrene is a highly valuable monomer in the polymer industry and is mainly produced by dehydrogenation (DDH) of ethylbenzene over potassium promoted iron oxide at high temperatures (Eq. (1)) [16]. Though this process is commercialized, it faces many hurdles as it is an endothermic reversible reaction ( Δ H 298 o = 117.6 kJ/mol) and restricted by thermodynamic equilibrium leading to the consumption of huge amount of energy (1.5 × 106 kcal/ton of styrene) [17,18]. An excess amount of superheated steam is provided to remove the coke that is formed on the catalyst surface during reaction along with keeping the reactant partial pressure low. To eliminate these problems, catalytic oxidative dehydrogenation in the presence or co-feeding of O2, NOx, SO2, or CO2 is regarded as a thermodynamically beneficial process [19]. However, the use of O2 causes over-oxidation and generating unwanted hydrocarbons and carbon oxides. In comparison, NOx and SO2 act as softer oxidants but are not appropriate for industrial production as several toxic and hazardous products (CS2, COS) are released during reaction. In this context, utilization of CO2 as a soft oxidant would not only have a positive impact on global carbon neutrality but also provide many advantages from reaction point of view, such as suppression of over oxidation, triggering a higher reaction rate by altering the oxidative dehydrogenation pathway, minimizing hot spot phenomena, reduce coke formation by removal of deposited carbon through the Boudouard equilibrium (Eq. (4)) and consequently less catalyst deactivation, and reducing the partial pressure of the ethylbenzene (Eqs. (1)–(3)) [19,20]. Noteworthy, addition of CO2 shifts the thermodynamic equilibrium towards the product side as generated hydrogen is removed through the reverse water gas shift (RWGS) reaction between H2 and CO2. This leads to improve in catalytic activity and reduce energy consumption (1.9 × 105 kcal/ton of styrene) [17]. To date, a variety of transition metal oxides (Fe, V, Cr, Ce based), mixed metal oxides, metal oxides, and carbon supports as well some promoters effects have been studied for the oxidative dehydrogenation of ethylbenzene with CO2 [16,19]. Among all, a catalyst comprising of Fe (+3) and V (+5) metal centers has received particular interest as these centers are redox active [16]. Further, the synergistic effect of acidic and basic properties of a catalyst plays a crucial role as shown by Sato et al. [21]. Likewise, the use of carbon supports for this reaction has gained momentum as they offer high surface area, easy surface modification, and most importantly surface oxygenated groups which influence dehydrogenation reaction. Rao et al. studied the effect of hydroxylation defects on MWCNTs prepared by hydrothermal, ball-milling, and ultrasonic treatments for CO2 ODH reaction [22]. It was found that the hydroxylation enhances the defect density which finally improves catalytic performances. Recently, Kim et al. prepared a N doped Fe-graphite catalyst through a mechanochemical process that showed stable performances in the CO2 ODH reaction of ethylbenzene at low temperatures [23]. Nevertheless, there is a lack of suitable catalysts for this reaction that can be prepared easily. To think of this matter, we have prepared a series of heteroatoms (N, P, S) doped Fe-carbon sphere catalysts by a simple hydrothermal process for the CO2 mediated oxidative dehydrogenation of ethylbenzene and showed the impact of the presence of the heteroatoms. Further, the benefit for selecting CO2 as soft oxidant were also explored by comparison with N2 as inert medium. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials and reagents All chemicals utilized in this study were commercially available and used without any further purification. Fe(NO3)3. 9H2O (98%, SRL India) and p-toluenesulfonic acid (99.5%) were obtained from Sisco Research Laboratories, India. Phosphoric acid (85% aq.) and Melamine (99%) were purchased from Alfa Aesar, USA. Sucrose (GR) was acquired from Mark, Germany. Ethylbenzene (99.8%) was provided by ThermoFisher scientific, USA. 2.2 Preparation of catalysts The catalysts were prepared after slight modifying a procedure reported elsewhere, as described below [24]. 2.2.1 Preparation of N doped Fe-carbon sphere catalyst This catalyst was prepared by the sonicating amixture of 2 g sucrose, 1 g melamine, and 0.25 g Fe(NO3)3. 9H2O in a 250 mL round bottom flask containing 60 mL water for 30 min. Once, the reaction mixture had turned completely pale yellow, it was subjected to hydrothermal treatment in 100 mL Teflon tube autoclave at 453 K for 24 h. Then, the autoclave was cooled to room temperature, and subsequently, the product was recovered by filtration and washed with sufficient water. Finally, obtained black material was carbonized at 873 K for 2 h in a quartz tube with a temperature rate of 5 K/min. This catalyst is denoted as Fe-N-C. 2.2.2 Preparation of N, S, and N, P co-doped Fe-carbon sphere catalysts For N, S co-doped carbon sphere, 2 g sucrose, 1 g melamine, 1 g p-toluenesulfonic acid and 0.25 g Fe(NO3)3. 9H2O while for N, P co-doped carbon sphere 2 g sucrose, 1 g melamine, 1 g phosphoric acid, and 0.25 g Fe(NO3)3. 9H2O was taken in a 250 mL round bottom flask containing 60 mL water respectively followed by sonication for 30 min. At the end of sonication, the p-toluenesulfonic acid-containing mixture became pale yellow while the phosphoric acid-containing mixture turned pale yellow to white. Afterward, similar procedures such as hydrothermal treatment, filtrations, and carbonization were followed as N doped iron sphere described above. After carbonization, N, S, and N, P co-doped carbon sphere catalysts are termed Fe-N-S-C and Fe-N-P-C. 2.2.3 Preparation Fe-carbon sphere catalyst Briefly, 2 g sucrose and 0.25 g Fe(NO3)3. 9H2O were dissolved in 60 mL water and followed all necessary steps as in the preparation of Fe-N-C or Fe-N-S-C or Fe-N-P-C catalysts. This as-synthesized catalyst after carbonization is named Fe-C. 2.3 Catalytic activity studies The efficacy of each carbon sphere catalyst was tested at atmospheric pressure in a downflow fixed bed reactor, where 0.15 g (100–120 mesh) catalyst was loaded into a quartz reactor (I.D. 9 mm) and finally placed into a furnace. The reaction temperature was controlled throughout the reaction by using a K-type thermocouple. The oxidative dehydrogenation reaction was studied in a range of temperatures Prior to the reaction, the catalyst was pre-treated at 823 K for 1 h under N2 (purity 99.999%) atmosphere (10 mL/min). Afterward, the reaction temperature was maintained (723–823 K) by introducing CO2/N2 (purity 99.999%) gas (10 mL/min). Finally, the reaction was begun by injecting ethylbenzene (1 mL/h) through a liquid feed pump. The liquid reaction mixture (benzene, toluene, styrene, ethylbenzene) was trapped in an ice-cold trap at regular time intervals while the gaseous products were directly sent to a gas chromatograph through a heated line connected with gas sampling valves. The confirmation and quantification of liquid products were achieved by manually injecting the reaction mixture on an Agilent 7890 B gas chromatography equipment fitted with FID using the HP FFAP column. A two-column assembly i.e. Porapak and Molecular Sieve Packed (Agilent) columns with valve switching were used for the separation of CO2, CH4, CO, and H2 gasses in TCD. The chromatograms of all detected products are provided in Figs. S1–S3. The ethylbenzene conversion and styrene selectivity were determined by applying the following equations. The carbon balance was found 88 to 95%. The ethylbenzene conversion and styrene selectivity were calculated by applying the following equations. Conv ersi on ( % ) = ( 1 − Ethy lben zen e ( out ) Ethy lben zen e ( in ) ) × 100 Selectivity ( % ) = ( Styren e ( in ) ( Ethylbenzen e ( in ) − Ethylbenzen e ( out ) ) ) × 100 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Physicochemical characterizations The structural information of carbon sphere catalysts is investigated by X-ray diffraction analysis and depicted in Fig. 1 . Two broad reflections in the XRD pattern at 2θ = ∼ 21–25° and 44° describe the (002) and (100) planes of the nanocrystalline graphitic domain within the carbon regime (JCPDS No. 89−8487) [2,25]. Again, the Fe-N-C catalysts exhibit two sharp diffraction peaks at 44.7° and 44.8° (Fig. 2 ) corresponding to the (110) and (031) plane of metallic Fe (JCPDS No. 06–0696) and iron carbide (Fe3C) (JCPDS No. 35–0772) [26–28]. Since ample amount of binding sites (N species) are available to capture or reduce the iron either through iron and carbon bond or through a donation of electrons from nitrogen. Despite not having any N heteroatom in the Fe-C catalyst, holds a higher amount of Fe species as it is physically trapped inside the carbon framework which is also evident from HRTEM [28]. Upon carbonization, the Fe species finally turns out to be an oxide form at 35.45° (magnetite Fe3O4, JCPDS No. 00–001–111). However, the ICP-OES analysis (Table 3) suggested the Fe amount is too low to appear in any particular crystalline form in XRD pattern of Fe-C-N-P catalyst. Interestingly, the metallic Fe, Fe3C crystalline phase is also possible to observe in the case of Fe-N-S-C along with a small shifting towards a lower 2θ angle. Upon moving from Fe-N-C to Fe-N-S-C catalysts, an increase in defect sites is noticed from Raman analysis (Fig. 2) as sulfur heteroatom is embedded inside carbon matrix. Since, the covalent radius of carbon (rcov: 0.73 Å) is much smaller than that of sulfur (rcov: 1.04 Å) resulting in increased interplanar distance and displacement of Fe, Fe3C peaks at lower 2θ angle [27]. Furthermore, the degree of structural deformation is disclosed in Fig. 2 by Raman spectroscopy. All carbon sphere catalysts have two typical D and G bands that are visible at around 1348 cm−1 and 1578 cm−1 respectively. The origination of the G band is associated with the in-plane vibration of sp2 aromatic carbon while the D band corresponds to the disorder caused by the defect and dislocation within the carbon framework [2]. Generally, the extent of the disorder, defect sites, or planarity is expressed by the relative intensity of the D and G bands. The obtained ID/IG value follows the order of Fe-N-S-C (1.23)> Fe-N-P-C(0.98)> Fe-N-C (0.89)>Fe-C(0.82) indicating that the heteroatoms play a great role in order to increase the disorders or defect sites of carbon catalyst. It is also noted that the co-doping by two heteroatoms (Fe-N-P-C and Fe-N-S-C) induces more structural deformation rather than a single doping carbon sphere catalyst (Fe-N-C). The morphological details of hydrothermally prepared carbonized samples were examined through FESEM and displayed in Figs. 3 –5(a, b). All samples after carbonization emerge as a mostly discrete sphere with a smooth surface regardless of any dopants but vary in size distributions. It is noted that the Fe-C catalyst possesses a variable-shaped microsphere with a mean diameter of 2.4 μm slightly lower than the other three (∼3.1–4.5 μm). Thus, it is believed that in absence of heteroatoms (N, S, P) carbon skeleton experiences a shrinkage. However, a clear insight into microstructural properties has been paid by using HRTEM, where Fe-C and Fe-N-C catalysts appear as a quasi-carbon sphere (Fig. 3(c)) and hollow carbon sphere (Fig. 4 (e) & (f)), while the other two (Fe-N-S-C and Fe-N-P-C) exhibit perfect sphere (Figs. 5 (c–f) & 6 (c–f)). Based on literature reports and microstructural analysis, a plausible reaction mechanism for the formation of carbon spheres is established (Scheme 2 ) [29–32]. Generally, the hydrolysis of sucrose to glucose and fructose monomer is the primary step in the formation of a carbon sphere, where sucrose hydrolysis is initiated either in presence of hydronium ion, originating from autoionization of water or in presence of any acid. But the latter one is effective as the hydrolysis rate increases enormously by acid catalysis. Then, the formed monomers undergo decomposition reactions (dehydration, decarbonylation, and aromatization) to form soluble macromolecules (1,6-anhydroglucose, furyl, and 1,2,4-benzenetriol) followed by polymerization or cross linking originated from intermolecular dehydration of formed macromolecules, linear or branchlike oligosaccharides, and other molecules (if present) . If the concentration of polymeric solution meets the critical supersaturation point, then burst nucleation happens, where each nucleus starts growing uniformly by diffusion to the surface of the chemical species present in the solution and is eventually obtained as particles. Finally, the aggregation of high-density particles compactly results in a carbon sphere. Therefore, to reach the threshold of supersaturation point, the concentration of macromolecules should be high enough as we know polymerization of the pentagonal and heptagonal ring is the second crucial step to getting a carbon sphere. In the case of the Fe-C catalyst, there was not any acid to be used during the hydrothermal process so slow hydrolysis took place in presence of autoionized H + [31]. Thus, that hydrothermal condition was not sufficient to reach the supersaturation point which may be the main reason why a perfect carbon sphere does not appear. Though in the case of Fe-N-C catalyst any acid was not used the existence of melamine somehow manages optimum concentration to attain supersaturation point for burst nucleation which causes the formation of carbon spheres. The high-resolution HRTEM images suggested it seems more like a hollow sphere (Fig. 4(e)&(f)) having various internal diameters of 20–32 nm and shell thickness of 3.2–4 nm. This may be due to the incomplete polymerization of melamine and macromolecules leading to the recrystallization during the growth of nuclei. On the other hand, the utilization of acids such as (H3PO4 and p-toluenesulfonic acid) triggers hydrolysis rate in the case of Fe-N-S-C and Fe-N-P-C catalysts and can easily attain the desired macromolecules concentration at which burst nucleation takes place by the overcoming of supersaturation point easily. Finally, high-energy particles are assembled tightly and appear as a perfect sphere. In a word, those acids not only help in hydrolysis and achieving supersaturation points but also make the sphere formation feasible by coupling with macromolecules. As Raman's analysis has suggested, the introduction of binary dopants is the main reason for creating enormous disorder or defect sites in the carbon skeleton. These defect sites might minimize the ring strain and help in the formation of a perfect carbon sphere. Additionally, high-angle annular dark-field scanning transmission electron microscopy (HAADF-STEM) was introduced to survey the existence of Fe species. As can be seen from (Figs. 3–5), all carbon sample surfaces appear with uniform brightness. So, one can think Fe might exist as isolated species but map images suggested the good distribution of Fe species throughout the carbon surface (Figs. 3(g), 4(l), 5(l) & 6(l)). This may be due to a few reasons reported elsewhere such as (i) high surface area of carbon, (ii) high nitrogen amount, (iii) utilization of oxygen-enriched precursor, and (iv) low iron amount [33]. Again, the map images of N dopant for Fe-N-S-C (Fig. 5(j)) and Fe-N-P-C (Fig. 6(j)) catalysts show the higher density of N in the center of the carbon sphere, implying the N doping is not restricted by the other dopants rather homogeneous over the sphere [34]. The porosity and BET surface area of Fe-carbon sphere catalysts are examined by N2 adsorption-desorption analysis and obtained isotherms are displayed in Fig. 7 . A classical feature of type IV isotherms with the variable shape of hysteresis indicates different textural properties. In each case, an ample amount of N2 uptake is found at a lower pressure region (P/P0 =0–0.1), which is a good sign of having a considerable amount of microporosity, especially for Fe-N-C catalyst [35]. However, the desorption branches of Fe-C, Fe-N-S-C, and Fe-N-P-C catalysts are affected by the cavitation and turn out as H3 hysteresis due to the formation of slit-like pores by the aggregation of plate-like particles [36]. Again, the persistence of H3 hysteresis up to low relative pressure (P/P0 < 0.4) is an indication of kinetic effect (diffusion limitation). Interestingly, an open H4 type of hysteresis can be seen in the case of Fe-N-C, implying the co-existence of micro and mesopores which are very frequently observed in hierarchical carbon and mesoporous zeolite [36]. The pore size distribution derived from the NLDFT method in Fig. 7(inset) reinforces the hierarchical porosity of the Fe-N-C catalyst. The unusual open H4 hysteresis may be caused either by the diffusion hindrance or by the strong interaction between N2 with high energetic sites. The surface area of synthesized catalysts follows the order of Fe-N-C> Fe-N-S-C> Fe-N-P-C where highest surface area (194 m2/g) of Fe-N-C is mainly accounted for by the hollow sphere structure of the catalyst [37]. Upon co-doping, surface area decreases substantially as perfect sphere formation takes place along with the insertion of a greater number of heteroatoms. However, the Fe-N-P-C catalyst possesses a lower surface (67 m2/g) area as compared to Fe-N-S-C (112 m2/g) due to having the highest amount of heteroatoms, shown in XPS [2]. XPS analysis of all catalysts provides deep insight into the surface elemental composition. The asymmetric nature of C (1 s) core-level spectra of all synthesized catalysts indicates the existence of different bonding environments of carbon, shown in Fig. 8 . The deconvolution of C (1 s) results in five distinct peaks, related to the sp2 C = C (peak 1, 284.6 eV), sp3 CC (peak 2, 285.51–285.68 eV), CO/CO-C/C-heteroatom (Peak 3, ca. 286.25–286.58 eV), C = O (peak 4, 287.2–287.55 eV), and O = CO/C = N (peak 5, 288.04–288.66 eV) species respectively [2,32,38]. Further, the calculation of atomic concentration (Table 1 ) shows a decrease in the concentration ratio of sp2 C = C and sp3 CC species upon the introduction of heteroatoms inside the carbon framework. This fact supports the Raman analysis results, related to the induction of defect sites by heteroatoms. Despite having similar kinds of carbon species within all catalysts, their variable atomic concentrations make them different from each other to catalyze different reactions. Earlier, our group showed the significance of O = CO species for glycerol acetalization reaction [32]. However, Kim et al. showed the effect of surface C = O species for oxidative dehydrogenation of ethylbenzene [28]. The deconvoluted O (1 s) spectra (Fig. 9 ) of Fe-C, Fe-N-C, and Fe-N-P-C catalysts are each made of three peaks, associated with C = O (peak 1, 530.56–531.7 eV), COH (peak 2, 532.36–532.72 eV) and O = CO (peak 3 533.15–533.6 eV) species [32]. However, the O = CO species is not found in the case of Fe-N-S-C catalyst (Fig. 8(c)). This result suggests the absence of surface COOH species in this catalyst and also confirms the appearance of a peak at 288.46 eV (peak 5) in the C (1 s) spectrum is solely responsible for C = N species (Fig. 8(c)). Notably, the calculated atomic percentages suggest the surface is mainly enriched by COH species (Table 2 ). Fig. 10 shows the N(1 s) core level spectra of Fe-N-C, Fe-N-S-C, and Fe-N-P-C catalysts, four distinctive peaks are visible for each catalyst which are assigned for the presence of pyridinic N (peak 1, 398.01–398.29 eV), pyrrolic N (peak 2, 399.11–399.45 eV), quaternary N (peak 3, 399.22–400.33 eV), and several N oxides (peak 4, 400.71–401.31 eV) species respectively [39]. Interestingly, it is seen in Table 2, that sulfur and phosphorus induce more nitrogen in the carbon surface for Fe-N-S-C and Fe-N-P-C catalyst as compared to only nitrogen-doped catalysts (Fe-N-C). Hence co-doping plays a beneficial role in inserting more nitrogen species and their distributions. However, the concentration of pyridinic N (Table 2) dominates with an order of pyridinic N >quaternary N > N-oxide > pyrrolic N for all three catalysts despite having a co-doping effect. The pyrrolic species is thermally unstable as it might transform into quaternary N at higher temperatures [40]. Several theoretical experimental studies prevailed that the carbon catalyst having a greater amount of pyridinic N species can be favorable for CO2 adsorption through an association between N lone pair and C of CO2 but their interaction sometimes varies in presence of other dopants. In the case of the Fe-N-S-C catalyst (Fig. 11 (a)), the deconvoluted S (2p) spectra consist of four peaks. The one set of doublets features at ca. 164.73 (peak 1) and 165.77 (peak 2) eV from the spin-orbit coupling of S (2p), can be identified for the interaction of sulfur and carbon (C-S-C 2p 3/2 and C-S-C 2p ½) in thiophene species. However, another interaction is found at ca. 167.82 (peak 3) and 170.05 (peak 4) eV, ascribing the presence of terminal C-SO2 and C-SO3 species [2,32]. It is noted from the relative atomic concentration that about 98% of sulfur species exist in the form of C-SO2 and C-SO3 and can be efficient to work as Brønsted acidic sites (Table 3 ). On the other hand, the deconvoluted P (2p) of Fe-N-P-C catalyst (Fig. 11(b)) gives rise to two peaks, indicating different bonding fashion of phosphorus in the carbon framework. Though the stability of phosphorus species is still a matter of debate at high temperatures [41]. But the peaks at ca. 132.64 (peak 1) and 134.92 (peak 2) eV assure the existence of pentavalent tetracoordinate C3PO and C2PO2/CPO3 species [42]. Both species are located at the edge of the carbon surface. The C3PO helps to link the carbon layers while the C2PO2/CPO3 species mainly act as Brønsted acidic sites. In addition, this catalyst contains a significant amount of acidity as 47% of the total atomic concentration of phosphate (Table 3), acts as an acidic site. This result further suggests, that the peak at 532.36 (peak 2) eV in the O (1 s) spectrum (Fig. 9(d)) of Fe-N-P-C catalyst also may be caused by the P-O along with COH species [42]. Apart from this, diversity in the distribution of iron species is found in Fe (2p) spectra for all catalysts (Fig. 12 ). Owing to having a lower content of iron, poor signals are obtained. In the case of Fe-C catalyst (Fig. 12(a)), one pair of spin-orbit peaks arise at ca. 709.9 (2p3/2, peak 1) and 724.51(2p1/2, peak 5) eV are due to the presence of Fe2+. However, another pair at ca. 712.7 (2p3/2, peak 2) and 727.2 (2p1/2, peak 6) eV guarantees the co-existence of Fe3+ [43,44]. This observation further strengthens the information about the existence of Fe3O4 obtained from XRD (Fig. 1). Additionally, three other peaks at ca. 716.95 (peak 3), 720.69 (peak 4), and 730.88 (peak 7) eV are the satellite peaks of Fe2+ and Fe3+ respectively [43,45]. In contrast, one pair of Fe3+ spin-orbit peaks and metallic iron peaks are found in the case of Fe-N-C and Fe-N-S-C catalysts (Fig. 12(b) & (c)) [46]. Where the slight change in the binding energy of Fe3+ peak as compared to Fe-C catalyst indicates that the surface may be electronically modified. Since nitrogen dopant improves the electron mobility of the carbon material, causing induces more electron density around Fe3+ which ultimately helps to shift the binding energy downwards. This observation combined with XRD results led us to suggest the existence of Fe3+ in the form of Fe3C in Fe-N-C and Fe-N-S-C catalysts. However, in the case of the Fe-N-P-C catalyst, the iron is present in the state of Fe0, Fe2+, and Fe3+ (Fig. 12(d)). It is worth noting from Table 3, the iron content found from XPS varies significantly in the order of Fe-N-P-C (at.%= 0.1%) < <Fe-C (at.%= 0.3) = Fe-N-S-C (at.%= 0.3) < Fe-N-C (at.%= 1.4), demonstrating the impact of different dopants on the loading of Fe during the synthesis. The maximum iron loading in the Fe-N-C catalyst is probably due to the presence of N dopants. The comparable atomic radius and higher electronegativity difference of N with C accelerate electron mobility and polarize electron cloud over the carbon surface which leads to enhanced charge distribution [3,39]. This phenomenon may be responsible for maximum iron intake. Whereas, S dopant is unable to develop adequate charge distribution despite bearing a similar kind of electronegativity to that of carbon as they differ in atomic radius substantially [40]. As a result, the Fe-N-S-C catalyst shows similar iron acceptance to the Fe-C catalyst. While preparing the Fe-N-P-C catalyst by sonication, the color changed from pale yellow to white with the addition of H3PO4. This indicates the formation of a complex Fe[HPO4]+ by capturing Fe3+ ions which may be the reason why Fe3+ is no longer available to interact with the dopants present in the carbon framework. Therefore, a lower amount of iron is found in Fe-N-P-C catalyst. Meanwhile, a variable amount of iron species has been washed away due to the effects of dopant as well as synthesis conditions. The thermal stability of a catalyst is a salient parameter for a heterogeneous catalyst, especially for high-temperature gas-phase reactions. To check that, thermogravimetric analysis was carried out under inert conditions and displayed in Fig. 13 . The nonlinear TGA profile of the aforementioned catalysts conferred the catalyst has variable thermal stability. The first mass loss in the temperature range 400–405 K for all catalysts is analogous to the loss of physisorbed water molecule molecules [2,32]. However, the mass loss found above 870 K, corresponds to the decomposition of mainly phenolic species attached to the carbon framework, indicating, that performing a reaction beyond this is not worth it. In addition, Fe-C and Fe-N-P-C catalysts encountered a little mass loss in the range of 620–650 K. The mass loss for Fe-C catalyst is mainly due to the combustion of acidic sites (anhydrides species) while for Fe-N-P-C catalyst it is related to the combustion of acidic sites along with C-P-O species [41,47]. This observation supports well with earlier reports. Interestingly, no loss is observed in the case of Fe-N-C and Fe-N-S-C catalysts in the range of 400–870 K, which is a good indication to perform a gas phase reaction in this temperature region. 3.2 Catalytic activity study 3.2.1 The behavioral aspect of as-synthesized catalysts on direct dehydrogenation of ethylbenzene (DDH) Primarily, the ethylbenzene dehydrogenation reaction was conducted by using as-synthesized catalysts without oxidative conditions to find a suitable catalyst. The direct dehydrogenation of ethylbenzene produces styrene as the main product and side-chain cracking results in toluene, benzene, and CH4 as side products. Though the ethylbenzene conversion vs TOS profile at 723 K shows a steady performance for 8 h ethylbenzene conversion is not significant (Fig. 14 (a)). Still, Fe-N-C shows high conversion among all four catalysts. The active phase that is responsible for low temperature is not clear. Still, circumstantial results indicate the Fe3C phase of the Fe-N-C catalyst which may be the active site for this dehydrogenation reaction as reported earlier. Fe3C unit cell has 12 iron and 3 carbon atoms. The iron comes up with the adsorption sites for the ethylbenzene, thus higher iron-containing catalyst may tend to be proportional to the conversion. Even, though the Fe-N-S-C catalyst also contains the Fe3C phase the estimated quantity (0.3%) is too low to make a difference in conversion from low iron-containing other (Fe-C and Fe-N-P-C) catalysts. However, by increasing the temperature from 723 to 823 K, a noteworthy enhancement of ethylbenzene conversion is observed irrespective of any four catalysts. Ethylbenzene dehydrogenation being an endothermic reaction can work effectively at high temperatures as equilibrium shifts towards the product sides. Again Table 3 shows the low iron (0.3%) content of Fe-N-P-C catalyst but has the higher conversion throughout the 8 h TOS as compared to the high iron (1.4%) content of Fe-N-C catalyst. Therefore, the ethylbenzene conversion is not only controlled by the iron content at high temperatures. Kim et al. categorized three factors: iron content, C = O/N-functional groups, and defect sites that could be a contributor to ethylbenzene dehydrogenation reaction over Fe-based graphite catalyst [23]. From the O(1 s) core level spectra, the C = O atomic concentration of all catalysts follows the order of Fe-N-C<Fe-N-S-C<Fe-N-P-C while the total atomic concentration of N species follows the sequence of Fe-N-C<Fe-N-S-C<Fe-N-P-C. These observations imply neither of them is directly responsible for the catalytic conversion of ethylbenzene. Hence, to find out the role of defect sites, the styrene formation rate is correlated with ID/IG value, as shown in (Fig. 14(a)). It is noticed that with an increase in defect sites (ID/IG), the ethylbenzene conversion steadily rises at 823 K but not at 723 K. Where iron content controls the ethylbenzene conversion. Hence, iron content and ID/IG ratio are the two important parameters for direct ethylbenzene dehydrogenation. In addition, the maximum selectivity of styrene is observed for the Fe-N-C catalyst at both temperatures (723 and 823 K) throughout the 8 h induction process (Fig. 15 (a) &(d)). Qui et al. stated that benzene formation is promoted by the surface COH and N-oxides species as they catalyze the cracking reaction of ethylbenzene, leading to the decrease in styrene selectivity. As displayed in Table 2, the benzene being the major by-product can easily diffuse through small pores and starts producing more with time for Fe-C, Fe-N-S-C, and Fe-N-P-C. The combination of lower atomic concentration of COH species and hierarchical pore structure of Fe-N-C catalyst ensures highest selectivity of styrene [48]. However, the worst selectivity is shown by the Fe-N-S-C catalyst after 8 h of reaction, which could be accompanied by the presence of the highest concentration of N-oxide along with COH species (Table 2) [48]. 3.2.2 Performance of as-synthesized catalysts in oxidative (CO2) dehydrogenation of ethylbenzene (DDH) CO2-mediated oxidative dehydrogenation of ethylbenzene over acidic-basic carbon catalyst follows a little different pathway compared to direct dehydrogenation, where the reaction starts with simple dehydrogenation and later proceeds by oxidative dehydrogenation. In simple, the efficient CO2 activation, rate of reverse water gas shifting (RWGS) reaction, and concentration of C = O species are the few deciding factors in CO2 mediated-dehydrogenation [19,28,49]. In order to witness the role of CO2, the obtained Fe-carbon sphere catalysts have been attempted for the same reaction at three different temperatures by keeping other reaction parameters constant (Fig. 16 ). It is found that the ethylbenzene conversion increases with temperature as a higher temperature can be able to overcome the thermodynamic limit of an endothermic reaction [49]. However, the conversion of the as-synthesized catalysts at each temperature follows a similar trend of Fe-N-C > Fe-C > Fe-N-S-C > Fe-N-P-C (Fig. 16(a)). Among all N species, Pyridinic N sites are majorly accountable for CO2 activation through the interaction between nitrogen lone pair and C of CO2 [50,51]. In the case of Fe-N-C catalyst, the highest conversion is related to the efficient CO2 activation as well as the alleviation of RWGS reaction by the Fe3C phase. It is reported that Fe3C can act as active sites in RWGS reactions [52–54]. So, consumption of formed H2 through reverse water gas shifting (RWGS) reaction, compels the ethylbenzene to be converted more. Besides, the highest amount of surface C = O species also helps the weakening of α -hydrogen of ethylbenzene [28]. Despite the presence of the highest amount of surface pyridinic N sites in Fe-N-S-C and Fe-N-P-C catalysts, they are unable to perform like Fe-N-C because other dopants i.e. sulfur and phosphorus restrict the efficient adsorption and subsequent activation of CO2 through their acidic nature. In particular, Brønsted acidic sites such as C-SO3, C-SO2, C3PO, and C2PO2/CPO3 are much suitable for the adsorption of basic molecules such as NH3, pyridine, etc. [55]. The activation of CO2 is predicted by changing the bond angle from linear geometry [19]. Hence, Brønsted acidic sites may either impede the acidic CO2 molecule to be adsorbed on the surface or do not allow a proper change of the bond angle, which in turn, could lead to inefficient activation. However, the dopant (N, S, P) interference is absent in the Fe-C catalyst, leading to better conversion than Fe-N-S-C and Fe-N-P-C catalysts. It is worth saying that the selectivity of styrene remains high and more or less unchanged for all catalysts at each temperature but the Fe-N-C catalyst appears as the best one in that (Fig. 16 (b–d)). Owing to the existence of a lesser amount of COH and N-oxide species, the cracking reaction is less favorable as compared to others [48]. Further, the styrene formation rate of Fe-N-C at different reaction temperatures is monitored with the CO2 conversion at a different time interval. It is noticed that the styrene formation rate increases from 723 K to 773 K and becomes twice as high at 823 K (Fig. 17 ). Likewise, CO2 consumption enhances with reaction temperature and reaches a maximum of 823 K (Fig. 17). This observation suggests that as the yield of styrene increases, more CO2 participates in the reaction. The CO2 conversion is mainly dependent on the abundance of H2 and the production of H2 is controlled by the reaction temperature. Thus, a combination of two at high temperatures achieves a high yield of styrene. The role of CO2 as a soft oxidant in this oxidative dehydrogenation is further compared with direct dehydrogenation. As indicated in Fig. 18 (a), the ethylbenzene conversion and styrene selectivity in presence of CO2 are much higher than that in N2. Initially, styrene and H2 form through direct dehydrogenation. But only in presence of CO2, the formed H2 can couple with activated CO2 and shifts the equilibrium of the dehydrogenation towards higher ethylbenzene conversion [49]. This coupling reaction accelerates the dehydrogenation reaction rate and suppresses the over-oxidation of products resulting in higher conversion and selectivity. However, the coke deposition that causes deactivation is very common in the ethylbenzene dehydrogenation reaction. In this regard, CO2 can also help as an oxidant for the effective removal of coke through oxidation and eventually improves the catalytic performance and catalyst lifetime [19]. It is found in the literature that the oxidative dehydrogenation of ethane using molecular O2, where CO and CO2 were produced as by-products where dehydrogenated products increased at high pressure of O2 with obtained selectivity of ethylene was around 80%. In our present study, the selectivity of dehydrogenated product is around 70% with a styrene formation rate of 15.6 mmol/g/h after 8 h of TOS in presence of CO2 as a soft oxidant [56]. It might have seemed from Table S1 that the ethyl benzene conversion and styrene selectivity of previously reported catalysts are better than our catalyst but the styrene formation rate demonstrates the overall superiority of our synthesized catalyst at 523 K temperature. Finally, the spent catalyst is regenerated in each cycle at 823 K under a CO2 atmosphere. The removal of coke in the form of CO is also evident by the gas chromatogram. In Fig. 18(b), there is not any drastic fall in catalytic activity observed even after three-time reuses. Interestingly, in the first cycle, CO2 conversion increases significantly, implying coke on the catalyst surface is not removed completely which in turn is removed during the reaction. However, the styrene selectivity after the third cycle decreases abruptly owing to the formation of benzene. The excellent catalytic activity of Fe-carbon sphere catalysts is rationalized readily on the basis of the catalytic functions that are present in the catalysts (Fig. 19). The porous carbon sphere encapsulates iron nanoparticles thereby perfectly stabilizing the metallic iron phase, while at the same time providing ready access of the substrate molecules to the iron surface atoms. Dehydrogenation of ethylbenzene at the iron atoms provides styrene that diffuses rapidly out of the porous carbon sphere. The hydrogen is transferred by surface diffusion or a molecular diffusion process that occurs within the sphere to a neighbouring Fe3C site. In parallel, CO2 is activated upon passing through the porous carbon sphere upon adsorption on pyridinic N sites. Spatially close hydrogen and carbon dioxide are then converted rapidly through the RWGS reaction over Fe3C active sites to carbon monoxide and water that diffuse out of the porous carbon sphere. The synergistic effect of the different sites in the Fe-carbon sphere catalysts thus gives rise to the high catalytic activity and excellent selectivity of Fe-carbon spheres in the CO2-mediated ethylbenzene dehydrogenation. 4 Conclusions In summary, a series of heteroatoms (N, P, S) doped Fe-carbon sphere catalysts have been prepared by the conventional hydrothermal approach and compared with regard to their catalytic efficiency for CO2-mediated oxidative dehydrogenation reaction. The appearance of a perfect carbon sphere for Fe-N-S-C and Fe-N-S-C catalysts is well explained based on HRTEM and FESEM results. XRD gives a brief idea about the formation of the nanocrystalline graphitic domain along with different iron species while Raman analysis unveils, that the compositional co-doping is responsible for introducing more structural disorders or defect sites in the carbon framework. Further, the existence of surface chemical species is confirmed by XPS analysis. Additionally, the nature of the heteroatom sites and their ability of charge distribution on the carbon surface has a great impact on the variation of the amount of iron from one catalyst to another. In the case of both direct and oxidative ethylbenzene dehydrogenation reactions, Fe-N-C turns out to be the best catalyst at a temperature of 823 K. The catalytic performance under oxidative conditions is much higher than that of direct dehydrogenation. This rationalizes readily as CO2 is efficiently activated by pyridinic N and can be able to favor RWGS by coupling with formed H2 over Fe3C active sites. However, the other acidic species such as C-SO3, C-SO2 and the C2PO2/CPO3 hinder the efficient CO2 adsorption in Fe-N-S-C and Fe-N-P-C catalysts, resulting in a low catalytic activity. It is envisaged that this study related to the utilization of CO2 as a soft oxidant and its behavior on different chemical species could be a prototype for designing carbon-based catalysts for industrial scale operations. coredata.dc:description: Distinctly shaping carbon materials together with doping is an excellent approach for tailoring advanced materials. In this study, a series of heteroatom (N, S, P)-doped Fe-carbon sphere catalysts were prepared by a hydrothermal process to explore the effect of unary and binary dopants on the CO2-mediated ethyl benzene oxidative dehydrogenation. Upon doing so, a transformation from quasi to hollow to perfect spheres was observed that takes place due to the increasing hydrolysis rate and attainment of supersaturation. It was shown that each type of heteroatom has a beneficial role in creating specific chemical entities as well as in defining the iron amount of the catalyst. Catalytic activity correlated with XPS and Raman analysis reveal that the direct dehydrogenation of ethylbenzene is controlled by the iron content at low temperatures, while defect sites are the controlling parameter at high temperatures. Under oxidative conditions, the N-doped hierarchical Fe-hollow sphere carbon (Fe-N-C) catalyst shows the highest catalytic performance among all synthesized catalysts due to the cooperative action of pyridinic N species and the Fe3C phase for CO2 activation as well as RWGS reaction promotion.
coredata.dc:title: Influence of heteroatom-doped Fe-carbon sphere catalysts on CO2- mediated oxidative dehydrogenation of ethylbenzene
